landmark_cases.case_name: Shreya Singhal v. Union of India
landmark_cases.summary: Struck down Section 66A of the IT Act as unconstitutional for violating freedom of speech
key_findings: Section 66A was vague and created an offense with undefined terms
Distinction made between discussion, advocacy, and incitement
Upheld constitutional validity of Section 69A and IT Blocking Rules
landmark_cases.legal_impact: Landmark judgment for online free speech in India

landmark_cases.case_name: Justice K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India
landmark_cases.summary: Recognized right to privacy as a fundamental right under Article 21
key_findings: Privacy is a fundamental right under the Constitution
Informational privacy recognized as a facet of the right to privacy
Established three-part test for privacy restrictions: legality, legitimate aim, proportionality
landmark_cases.legal_impact: Constitutional foundation for data protection laws in India

landmark_cases.case_name: Avnish Bajaj v. State (NCT of Delhi)
landmark_cases.summary: Case involving liability of Baazee.com CEO for obscene material sold on platform
key_findings: Examined intermediary liability before safe harbor provisions
Distinguished between platform and content provider liability
landmark_cases.legal_impact: Influenced development of intermediary liability provisions

landmark_cases.case_name: Facebook Inc. v. Union of India
landmark_cases.summary: Challenge to WhatsApp traceability requirements and transfer of cases to Supreme Court
key_findings: Balance between privacy and state security interests
Consideration of encryption technologies and traceability
landmark_cases.legal_impact: Important for understanding encryption regulation in India

hacking.title: Computer Hacking

legal_framework.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years or fine up to 5 lakh rupees or both

relevant_sections.individual_victims: Section 66 of the Information Technology Act
relevant_sections.corporate_victims: Section 66 with Section 43A for compensation from body corporate

File a complaint at the local police station or cyber crime portal (cybercrime.gov.in)
Provide all relevant details including timeline of the incident
Report to CERT-In if major system compromise
corporate: Preserve digital evidence and system logs
Document breach timeline and affected systems
Mandatory reporting to CERT-In within 6 hours
File formal police complaint with cyber cell

Report to cyber crime portal (cybercrime.gov.in)

corporate: Report to IT security team immediately
Preserve original phishing communication with headers
Report to financial institutions if credentials compromised
File official complaint with cyber cell
